items.title: Chicago federal judge temporarily blocks National Guard deployment in Illinois
items.standfirst: A federal judge on Thursday granted a partial restraining order to block the Trump administration's deployment of National Guard troops in Illinois, after state and local leaders objected to the deployment.
items.content: A federal judge on Thursday granted a partial restraining order to block the Trump administration's deployment of National Guard troops in Illinois, after state and local leaders objected to the deployment.

items.title: Israeli government approves framework "for the release of all of the hostages"

items.content: Trump says Hamas will likely release all Israeli hostages by early next week, as the "first phase" of a deal to end the war in Gaza is expected to take effect soon.

items.title: Israel and Hamas agree to first phase of Trump’s peace plan
items.standfirst: President Trump touted a landmark agreement to end the war in Gaza. Plus, two senior U.S. officials tell NBC News that 200 U.S. troops will be deployed to Israel, but not Gaza, to support an international security force. NBC News’ Garrett Haake reports.
items.content: President Trump touted a landmark agreement to end the war in Gaza. Plus, two senior U.S. officials tell NBC News that 200 U.S. troops will be deployed to Israel, but not Gaza, to support an international security force. NBC News’ Garrett Haake reports.

items.title: Israeli government approves framework for release of all remaining hostages, Netanyahu says
items.standfirst: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has posted on social media that his government approved a plan for the release of all remaining hostages in Gaza. The release of hostages is one aspect of President Trump's peace plan. The agreement would end the war in Gaza that has lasted just over two years. Will Todman, senior fellow at the Center for Strategic and International Studies' Middle East program, joins "The Daily Report" to discuss.
items.content: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has posted on social media that his government approved a plan for the release of all remaining hostages in Gaza. The release of hostages is one aspect of President Trump's peace plan. The agreement would end the war in Gaza that has lasted just over two years. Will Todman, senior fellow at the Center for Strategic and International Studies' Middle East program, joins "The Daily Report" to discuss.

items.title: Where does the deployment of National Guard troops stand?
items.standfirst: Separate courtrooms heard arguments Thursday over President Trump's efforts to deploy National Guard troops to American cities. CBS News Homeland Security Correspondent Nicole Sganga has more.
items.content: Separate courtrooms heard arguments Thursday over President Trump's efforts to deploy National Guard troops to American cities. CBS News Homeland Security Correspondent Nicole Sganga has more.

items.title: Judge temporarily blocks Trump’s effort to deploy national guard troops in Chicago
items.standfirst: Much-anticipated judgement centers on efforts by Trump administration to use troops to aid immigration crackdownA judge on Thursday temporarily blocked the deployment of the national guard in Chicago in a much-anticipated ruling about efforts by the Trump administration to use troops to help enforce immigration policy and also battle what it says are high crime rates.During arguments about the case, lawyers for the state of Illinois had called the sending of national guard soldiers to the city – which was opposed by Chicago and state political leaders – a constitutional crisis. Continue reading...

Continue reading...

items.title: Israel Implements Ceasefire After Hostage Deal With Hamas
Does Israel and Hamas signing the Gaza ceasefire deal mean the war is over?
items.standfirst: Israel and Hamas signed an agreement on Thursday to cease fire and free Israeli hostages in exchange for Palestinian prisoners in the first phase of US President Donald Trump's initiative to end the devastating two-year war in Gaza. The breakthrough has been met with joy and relief, but also caution for what this means in the long run.
items.content: Israel and Hamas signed an agreement on Thursday to cease fire and free Israeli hostages in exchange for Palestinian prisoners in the first phase of US President Donald Trump's initiative to end the devastating two-year war in Gaza. The breakthrough has been met with joy and relief, but also caution for what this means in the long run.

items.content: Israel and Hamas have reached an agreement for the "first phase" of a plan promoted by President Trump to end the war in Gaza. A ceasefire is expected to go into effect after an Israeli Cabinet vote.(Image credit: Abdel Kareem Hana)

items.title: Israel and Hamas agree to truce and hostage release
items.standfirst: Israel and Hamas have agreed to the "first phase" of a plan to end the war in Gaza, President Donald Trump announced on Wednesday, with both parties also acknowledging that a deal had been reached."I am very proud to announce that Israel and Hamas have both signed off on the first Phase of our Peace Plan," Trump wrote in a post on Truth Social
items.content: Israel and Hamas have agreed to the "first phase" of a plan to end the war in Gaza, President Donald Trump announced on Wednesday, with both parties also acknowledging that a deal had been reached."I am very proud to announce that Israel and Hamas have both signed off on the first Phase of our Peace Plan," Trump wrote in a post on Truth Social

ai_summary: Israel and Hamas agreed to the first phase of a ceasefire to end the war in Gaza.
President Trump touted the agreement as a landmark achievement to end the conflict.
Two U.S. officials said 200 troops will deploy to Israel to support an international force.
The Israeli government approved a plan for the release of all remaining hostages.
The agreement would end the war in Gaza, which has lasted just over two years.

items.title: Breaking down Letitia James' indictment
items.standfirst: New York Attorney General Letitia James has been indicted by a grand jury in Alexandria, Virginia. She faces two separate charges, one count of bank fraud and one count of false statements to a financial institution. CBS News' Jake Rosen and Katrina Kaufman report.
items.content: New York Attorney General Letitia James has been indicted by a grand jury in Alexandria, Virginia. She faces two separate charges, one count of bank fraud and one count of false statements to a financial institution. CBS News' Jake Rosen and Katrina Kaufman report.

items.title: Early details on New York AG Letitia James' indictment
items.standfirst: A grand jury in Virginia on Thursday indicted New York Attorney General Letitia James. James brought and won a civil fraud case against President Trump, his adult sons and the Trump organization, with Mr. Trump being ordered to pay $355 million for inflating property values. CBS News legal reporter Katrina Kaufman has more.
items.content: A grand jury in Virginia on Thursday indicted New York Attorney General Letitia James. James brought and won a civil fraud case against President Trump, his adult sons and the Trump organization, with Mr. Trump being ordered to pay $355 million for inflating property values. CBS News legal reporter Katrina Kaufman has more.

ai_summary: Letitia James was indicted on one count of bank fraud and one of false statements.
The indictment was filed by a federal grand jury in Alexandria, Virginia.
James called the indictment a "desperate weaponization of our justice system."
The case comes after Trump urged the Department of Justice to take action.
James stated, "I am not fearful, I am fearless" following the indictment.

items.content: Discord says that hackers made off with images of 70,000 users’ government IDs that they were required to provide in order to use the site. Like an increasing number of sites, Discord requires certain users to provide a photo or scan of their driver's license or other government ID that shows they…

items.title: Discord says hackers stole government IDs of 70,000 users
items.standfirst: As more sites require IDs for user age verification, expect more such breaches to come.
items.content: Discord says that hackers made off with images of 70,000 users’ government IDs that they were required to provide in order to use the site. Like an increasing number of sites, Discord requires certain users to provide a photo or scan of their driver's license or other government ID that shows they meet the minimum age requirements in their country. In some cases, Discord allows users to prove their age by providing a selfie that shows their faces (it’s not clear how a face proves someone’s age, but there you go). The social media site imposes these requirements on users who are reported by other users to be under the minimum age for the country they’re connecting from. “A substantial risk for identity theft” On Wednesday, Discord said that ID images of roughly 70,000 users “may have had government-ID photos exposed” in a recent breach of a third-party service Discord entrusted to manage the data. The affected users had communicated with Discord’s Customer Support or Trust & Safety teams and subsequently submitted the IDs in reviews of age-related appeals.Read full article Comments

items.title: ID photos of 70,000 users may have been leaked, Discord says
items.standfirst: The platform says hackers targeted a firm that helped to verify the ages of its users.
items.content: The platform says hackers targeted a firm that helped to verify the ages of its users.

ai_summary: Discord reported hackers stole images of 70,000 users' government IDs.
The IDs were required for age verification on the platform.
The hackers targeted a firm that helped verify user ages.
The breach highlights the increasing use of IDs for online verification.
Expect more such breaches as more sites require IDs.

clusters.title: AI models can acquire backdoors from surprisingly few malicious documents
clusters.neutral_headline: AI Models Can Acquire Backdoors from Surprisingly Few Malicious Documents

items.title: AI models can acquire backdoors from surprisingly few malicious documents
items.standfirst: Anthropic study suggests "poison" training attacks don't scale with model size.
items.content: Scraping the open web for AI training data can have its drawbacks. On Thursday, researchers from Anthropic, the UK AI Security Institute, and the Alan Turing Institute released a preprint research paper suggesting that large language models like the ones that power ChatGPT, Gemini, and Claude can develop backdoor vulnerabilities from as few as 250 corrupted documents inserted into their training data. That means someone tucking certain documents away inside training data could potentially manipulate how the LLM responds to prompts, although the finding comes with significant caveats. The research involved training AI language models ranging from 600 million to 13 billion parameters on datasets scaled appropriately for their size. Despite larger models processing over 20 times more total training data, all models learned the same backdoor behavior after encountering roughly the same small number of malicious examples.Read full article Comments

items.title: It's trivially easy to poison LLMs into spitting out gibberish, says Anthropic
items.standfirst: Just 250 malicious training documents can poison a 13B parameter model - that's 0.00016% of a whole dataset Poisoning AI models might be way easier than previously thought if an Anthropic study is anything to go on. …
items.content: Just 250 malicious training documents can poison a 13B parameter model - that's 0.00016% of a whole dataset Poisoning AI models might be way easier than previously thought if an Anthropic study is anything to go on. …

ai_summary: Anthropic study suggests "poison" training attacks don't scale.
Just 250 malicious documents can poison a 13B parameter model.
Poisoning AI models might be easier than previously thought.
The study indicates the ease of poisoning LLMs.
The malicious documents represent 0.00016% of a dataset.
